thread.title: Busline League runners prove fleet of foot in championships
thread.title_full: Busline League runners prove fleet of foot in championships

author: news@courierpublicationsllc.com (Ken Waltz)
title: Busline League runners prove fleet of foot in championships
text:
Busline League runners prove fleet of foot in championships Lincolnville's Dunton, Thibeault race to individual titles By Ken Waltz | Oct 15, 2015 Photo by: Ken Waltz View More... 
Damariscotta — Perhaps inspired by the little foot with the initial of their sidelined teammate's first and last name tied to their sneakers — or the fact they are just really fast — two Lincolnville Central School youngsters set the pace and led the pack during the Busline League middle school cross-country championships on Thursday, Oct. 15. 
In an event held on a glorious early-fall afternoon and in an idyllic setting at the fan-friendly hills and valleys of the Damariscotta River Association's Great Salt Bay Heritage Trails, young distance runners pushed themselves to the limit physically and mentally over the challenging 2.2-mile course. 
Lincolnville's Miranda Dunton capped an unbeaten season by pulling away for the individual win in the girls race, while Lynx teammate Hayden Thibeault finished first in the boys race. 
Thibeault won most races he participated in this season, but finished second once when he took a wrong turn on the course during one meet. 
The season had been off and running for weeks until Thursday, when individual and team championships were determined. The boys ran first and girls second. 
Lincolnville runners and coaches wore a little foot with the letter K on it to represent team member and eighth-grader Kristina Kelly, who was unable to participate in her final race due to a medical issue. Kelly is the girls team's second fastest runner and a key member of the LCS coed soccer team. 
Kelly was on hand to cheer on her teammates. 
Besides those from Lincolnville, many youngsters and their teams, in a geographically area from Searsport to Boothbay, performed well on the course, which included downhill starts and finishes, woods, long straight stretches near marshes and a few challenging hills. 
Video, complete individual and team results and links to more photos from the championship meet will appear later with this story. 
The league includes teams from Troy Howard Middle School of Belfast, Searsport District Middle School, Islesboro Central School, Medomak Middle School of Waldoboro, Great Salt Bay of Damariscotta, Camden-Rockport Middle School, Appleton Village School, Oceanside West of Thomaston/Rockland, St. George Elementary School, Boothbay Elementary Region School and Lincolnville Central School. 
During the regular season, there were 11 meets at 11 sites.
